Authors:
Tomoyuki Takano, Hisato Ikegaya, Hisayoshi Nozaki,
Hidetoshi Sakayama
Title:
Morphology, taxonomy and phylogenetic positions of two
strains of Spirogyra (Zygnematophyceae, Streptophyta) with replicate and
semi-replicate transverse walls
Keywords:
conjugation, molecular phylogeny, sexual reproduction,
Spirogyra, taxonomy, Zygnematophyceae
Abstract:
The characteristics of the transverse walls and the
morphology of conjugation are essential for species identification in
the genus Spirogyra. There are four types of transverse walls: plane,
replicate, semi-replicate, and colligate. Although recent cultural
studies identified 14 species of Spirogyra and resolved their
phylogenetic positions within the genus, species with semi-replicate and
colligate transverse walls have not been studied in culture and their
phylogenetic positions are unknown. Here we studied the morphology and
taxonomy of two Spirogyra strains with replicate transverse walls and
semi-replicate transverse walls in culture. Based on sexual reproduction
traits induced, the former strain chiA303 was identified as S.
crassispina and the latter strain wak305 was morphologically similar to
S. unduliseptum except for the zygospore ornamentation. Although S.
unduliseptum was previously known to perform only scalariform
conjugation, we observed three types of conjugation, scalariform,
lateral and terminal conjugation, in strain wak305. Molecular
phylogenetic analysis showed that S. crassispina was phylogenetically
separated from other species with replicate transverse walls. The strain
wak305 was phylogenetically separated from these two Spirogyra lineages
with replicate transverse walls.
